Award.AwardTitle: Role of Subgenomic RNAs in Genetic Recombination of Brome Mosaic Bromovirus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. RNA viruses are among the most challenging infectious agents. Some RNA viruses cause serious diseases in human beings, while other RNA viruses do so to livestock or to crop plants. One of the main problems limiting the control of RNA viruses is rapid change of their genetic information which leads to constant emergence of new viral strains. RNA recombination involves the exchange of viral RNA fragments and the strategies of RNA recombination are key tools needed for RNA viruses to secure their fast adaptation and evolution. In contrast to genetic recombination of DNA-based organisms including DNA viruses, RNA recombination in RNA viruses is not well studied. The Brome mosaic virus (BMV) system is an excellent well-elaborated model for the understanding of basic mechanisms of RNA recombination. In this project the research will focus on the characterization of the molecular factors that are responsible for efficient homologous BMV RNA-RNA crossovers. The project takes advantage of a previously localized region on the BMV RNA molecule that supports unusually high frequency of recombination (defined as the RNA3 intercistronic recombination hot-spot or "sgp") as well as a recently discovered novel subgenomic (sg) BMV RNA (named as "sgRNA3a") in order to elucidate which of the known multiple functions of the sgp is responsible for recombination. The experimental design of this project relies on testing of the modified BMV RNA3 constructs in a variety of both in vitro and in vivo assays. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its investigation of the roles of sgRNA molecules in a model RNA virus system. These studies will provide the scientists with new information about molecular strategies that are utilized by RNA viruses to condition the efficient genetic recombination. Results from these studies will contribute to a more integrated picture of recombination mechanisms that will be applicable to other RNA viruses.

Broader impacts of the project. This project will contribute significantly to our knowledge about viral molecular adaptations, and will help to draw analogies between DNA and RNA genetics, by using the BMV model system. BMV is a member of a larger RNA virus super-family, and its molecular strategies are common among other viruses. This research will provide students with hands-on training in the important areas of biochemistry, molecular biology, plant biology, and virology. The principal investigator teaches a molecular virology course and this work will train young virologists. Also, the principal investigator teaches an advanced course entitled "The RNA World". The principal investigator has a long record of undergraduate training including those from underrepresented groups. All the students will be encouraged to present their research at scientific meetings (e.g., Sigma Xi, American Society of Plant Biologists, American Society for Virology). The principal investigator's group maintains collaborations with the University of Chicago and with an Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry in Poznan, Poland, and keeps active contacts with several international virology groups. These interactions will enhance the exposure of the students to the international environment. The principal investigator is making efforts to disseminate science by translation of English works (has translated into Polish language a book by Matt Ridley "Red Queen, sex and evolution of human nature"). In general, social benefits of this project rely upon improvement of our understanding of RNA recombination in RNA viruses which will provide new potential means for control of these important infectious agents. It will also raise the scientific literacy of the public via outreach activities. By learning how to predict recombination hot-spots scientists will be able to design more stable viral vectors as important biotechnology tools.

POR.DRECONTENT: RNA viruses are important pathogens of humans, animals and plants. RNA viruses are those that use RNA molecules to store and transmit their own genetic information. These viruses characterize with the ability of quick changing, forming new viral strains and they quickly adapt to new environments.  These changes are possible to due to a relatively high mutation rates of their genomic RNAs which is in part possible via so called genetic recombination that happens among their RNA molecules. We have been studying RNA recombination for quite some time by using a plant virus called Brome mosaic virus (BMV) as a benign model RNA virus of plants.  In this project the research was conducted to identify factors that make possible the RNA recombination processes to occur.  One goal has been to locate regions on BMV RNA molecules that mediate recombination crossovers. We identified a central part in the middle of BMV RNA3 that mediates the crossovers efficiently. Then we mapped more closely the nucleotide sequences of this region that assisted the crosses.  Second goal has been to determine whether BMV-encoded proteins also mediate recombination. Here we identified at least two proteins, one being the so called coat protein (CP) that is responsible for the formation of BMV final capsid structures. Second protein being the replicase one, which is an enzyme that copies BMV RNAs into a high number of them.  Our observing the role of CP in mediating the recombination process has been a surprising discovery, because it means that CP is a multifunctional protein that not only builds up the viral capsids but also mediates recombination. Continuing our research we also observed a link between BMV RNA recombination and another process in plant cells called RNA interference (RNAi). RNAi serves as some sort of immune system in many organisms, including humans, animals and plants that chops up the invading viral RNAs into fragments and thus prevents viral infection. We have accomplished our task by infecting a model plant called Arabidopsis thaliana with BMV RNAs such that, if Arabidopsis missed a gene that was responsible for the RNAi activity, the formation of BMV RNA recombinants was significantly reduced.  Indeed we concluded that viral RNA recombination was inhibited when RNAi was impaired, meaning that there was a link to the RNAi activity.  This has been probably because the viral RNA fragments get joined back together (but not always joined precisely) and thus regenerated the modified BMV RNA recombinants. Finally, as a last task we tried to map other regions on all three BMV RNA molecules that mediated recombination crossovers among BMV RNA molecules. This objective has been achieved by co-inoculating several plant species with two related variants (strains) of BMV virus and after some incubation period the infecting virus was extracted back from those plants and their nucleotide sequences analyzed. POR.POR_COPY_TXT: RNA viruses are important pathogens of humans, animals and plants. RNA viruses are those that use RNA molecules to store and transmit their own genetic information. These viruses characterize with the ability of quick changing, forming new viral strains and they quickly adapt to new environments. These changes are possible to due to a relatively high mutation rates of their genomic RNAs which is in part possible via so called genetic recombination that happens among their RNA molecules. We have been studying RNA recombination for quite some time by using a plant virus called Brome mosaic virus (BMV) as a benign model RNA virus of plants. In this project the research was conducted to identify factors that make possible the RNA recombination processes to occur. One goal has been to locate regions on BMV RNA molecules that mediate recombination crossovers. We identified a central part in the middle of BMV RNA3 that mediates the crossovers efficiently. Then we mapped more closely the nucleotide sequences of this region that assisted the crosses. Second goal has been to determine whether BMV-encoded proteins also mediate recombination. Here we identified at least two proteins, one being the so called coat protein (CP) that is responsible for the formation of BMV final capsid structures. Second protein being the replicase one, which is an enzyme that copies BMV RNAs into a high number of them. Our observing the role of CP in mediating the recombination process has been a surprising discovery, because it means that CP is a multifunctional protein that not only builds up the viral capsids but also mediates recombination. Continuing our research we also observed a link between BMV RNA recombination and another process in plant cells called RNA interference (RNAi). RNAi serves as some sort of immune system in many organisms, including humans, animals and plants that chops up the invading viral RNAs into fragments and thus prevents viral infection. We have accomplished our task by infecting a model plant called Arabidopsis thaliana with BMV RNAs such that, if Arabidopsis missed a gene that was responsible for the RNAi activity, the formation of BMV RNA recombinants was significantly reduced. Indeed we concluded that viral RNA recombination was inhibited when RNAi was impaired, meaning that there was a link to the RNAi activity. This has been probably because the viral RNA fragments get joined back together (but not always joined precisely) and thus regenerated the modified BMV RNA recombinants. Finally, as a last task we tried to map other regions on all three BMV RNA molecules that mediated recombination crossovers among BMV RNA molecules. This objective has been achieved by co-inoculating several plant species with two related variants (strains) of BMV virus and after some incubation period the infecting virus was extracted back from those plants and their nucleotide sequences analyzed. The results of these analyses turned out to be very informative because we found many places were the analogous RNAs from two BMV strains have crossed with each other. By counting the number of recombinant molecules we could determine the frequency with which the recombination events did happen at any given region alongside the viral RNAs. Based on these results we concluded that BMV RNAs recombined very frequently during infection process such that almost every progeny RNA molecule was a recombinant. In summary by doing research within this project we have been able to pinpoint several important processes and features that do characterize the RNA recombination phenomenon in RNA viruses. Our studies will continue to identify and recognize other aspects of genetic RNA recombination such that this accumulated basic knowledge could then be used by others to develop efficient measures for controlling RNA viruses and the high variability of their genomes.
